results.title: Fire Departments Prepare for Fire Season
results.body:
Today firefighters from the Los Padres National Forest, Ventura County Fire, Santa Barbara County Fire, CAL FIRE/San Luis Obispo County Fire and CAL FIRE/Monterey are increasing their staffing levels, fire engines, bull dozers, fire crews, helicopters and air tankers for this fire season.

With a fourth year of drought and continuous record breaking temperature this winter, our wildland fire season situation on the Central Coast has unprecedented conditions. Wildfire intensity is influenced by three factors: Fuel Conditions, Topography and Weather.

While we do not know what the weather will bring this summer, we do know that our fuel conditions are severe with significant mortality in our brush, oaks and timber. Fire season is always difficult on the Central Coast, but under bad weather conditions this year the burning conditions will substantially challenge our firefighters, and threaten our communities.

label.eng: California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection

results.title: Fire crews in California increase staffing earlier
results.body:
SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- Fire agencies along California's central and southern coasts are ramping up staffing levels well before they normally do because of bone-dry conditions after four years of drought.

Ventura County Fire, Santa Barbara County Fire and state fire crews in San Luis Obispo County and the San Benito-Monterey area are adding firefighters, fire engines, bull dozers, helicopters and air tankers on Monday for this year's fire season.

The Los Padres National Forest is also adding firefighters and equipment.

The chance of a wildfire in California typically peaks in autumn. But fire officials say the ongoing drought has made wildfires a year-round concern in the state.

results.title: High Fire Season Starts Monday
results.body:
SANTA BARBARA COUNTY, Calif. -

High fire season officially starts Monday.

In a joint news release, five local fire agencies- the Los Padres National Forest, Ventura County Fire, Santa Barbara County Fire, CAL FIRE/San Luis Obispo County Fire and CAL FIRE/Monterey- announced an increase in staffing levels.

More fire engines, bulldozers, helicopters and air tankers will also be on standby.

Fire officials said this season will bring unprecedented conditions because of the four-year drought and record-breaking winter temperatures.

The lack of moisture has created more fire fuel.

"We are really dealing with something we haven't seen in years, with the drought. It's just making everything really dry and explosive. You're seeing a lot more dead vegetation. It's making our job tougher to fight these fires," said fire captain Sergio Sanchez.

The Santa Barbara County Fire Department wants everyone to be prepared.

Residents in wildland areas should maintain 100 feet of defensible space, have an evacuation plan in place and use outdoor powered equipment with care.

The fire department begins its annual fire season training on Monday at Lake Cachuma.

label.eng: California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection

results.title: Fire Crews Staffing Up Earlier in South, Central CA
results.body:
A wildfire spreading in Central Calif. near the Nevada border forced the evacuation of two towns in February. Fire officials say fire season used to start in late Spring but is now a year-round worry.

In a reflection of California's bone-dry conditions after four years of drought, fire agencies along the state's central and southern coasts are ramping up staffing levels well before they normally do.

Ventura County Fire, Santa Barbara County Fire and state fire crews in San Luis Obispo County and the San Benito-Monterey area are adding firefighters, fire engines, bull dozers, helicopters and air tankers on Monday for this year's fire season, fire officials announced. The Los Padres National Forest is also adding firefighters and equipment.

California Drought Images: Disappearing Water

Santa Barbara County Fire Capt. Dave Zaniboni tells the Los Angeles Times his department used to ramp up at the end of May or in June. But he said the state's drought has made the early call up the new normal.

State fire crews have responded to 640 fires since January, more than twice the number over similar periods before the drought, state fire spokeswoman Lynne Tolmachoff told the Times.

Southern California Wildfires

She said some state fire units began adding additional firefighters in March.

The chance of a wildfire in California typically peaks in autumn. But fire officials say the ongoing drought has made wildfires a year-round concern in the state.

California Wildfires

The concern is heightened in areas such as the central coast that have also experienced higher-than-normal temperatures this winter, fire officials said.

People there are being warned to create 100 feet of defensible space around their homes and use fire resistant building materials to harden the structures.

Dismal Snowpack in Sierras

People are also being urged to restrict their use of power equipment such as chain saws outdoors because more than 90 percent of wildfires are the result of human activity.

Published 2 hours ago

results.title: Fire crews in California increase staffing earlier
results.body:
SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- In a reflection of California's bone-dry conditions after four years of drought, fire agencies along the state's central and southern coasts are ramping up staffing levels well before they normally do.

Ventura County Fire, Santa Barbara County Fire and state fire crews in San Luis Obispo County and the San Benito-Monterey area are adding firefighters, fire engines, bull dozers, helicopters and air tankers on Monday for this year's fire season, fire officials announced. The Los Padres National Forest is also adding firefighters and equipment.

Santa Barbara County Fire Capt. Dave Zaniboni tells the Los Angeles Times (http://lat.ms/1FMudH6) his department used to ramp up at the end of May or in June. But he said the state's drought has made the early call up the new normal.

State fire crews have responded to 640 fires since January, more than twice the number over similar periods before the drought, state fire spokeswoman Lynne Tolmachoff told the Times.

She said some state fire units began adding additional firefighters in March.

The chance of a wildfire in California typically peaks in autumn. But fire officials say the ongoing drought has made wildfires a year-round concern in the state.

The concern is heightened in areas such as the central coast that have also experienced higher-than-normal temperatures this winter, fire officials said.

People there are being warned to create 100 feet of defensible space around their homes and use fire resistant building materials to harden the structures.

People are also being urged to restrict their use of power equipment such as chain saws outdoors because more than 90 percent of wildfires are the result of human activity.

results.title: Every day is fire season in drought-era California, experts say
results.body:
In drought-era California, does "fire season" mean anything?

Traditionally, the scorching, parched autumn was the period of greatest concern about wildfires, but experts say that after four desiccated years almost every day in the Golden State can be considered fire season.

Fire agencies in Santa Barbara County and other parts of the Central Coast are moving next week to increased levels of staffing and greater numbers of fire engines, bulldozers and air tankers available for dispatch. Before the drought, this ramp-up often occurred at the end of May or June, said Santa Barbara County Fire Capt. Dave Zaniboni. His department has already battled 70 small fires this year and sees no reason to hold off.

"Unfortunately, this is the new normal," Zaniboni said.

At the state level, some Cal Fire units started adding additional firefighters in March, said public information officer Lynne Tolmachoff. She noted that with the drought, "off-season" in firefighting has less significance than in previous years.

Since January, Cal Fire has responded to 640 fires, more than twice the number in similar periods in pre-drought years, Tolmachoff said. The year-round fires led the agency to keep 70 fire engines working over the winter compared with the 10 on off-season duty in normal years, she said.

Many Cal Fire crews are spending this weekend in Amador County training with the California National Guard. The training occurs annually, but Tolmachoff said it has extra urgency this year because Cal Fire calls on the guard for backup when it is battling multiple fires, a situation the drought makes more likely.

Jet Propulsion Laboratory climatologist Bill Patzert said that with high temperatures and dry vegetation, the West "is primed for fire" and rainstorms are unlikely before November.

"The drought is not going to get any better between now and the fall," Patzert said. "We are in an incendiary situation."

harriet.ryan@latimes.com

Follow @latimesharriet

Copyright © 2015, Los Angeles Times

label.eng: California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection

results.title: Cal Fire expecting intense fire season in 2015
results.body:
We are only four months into 2015 and already, Cal Fire crews have responded to nearly 150 wildfires across the state. We are only four months into 2015 and already, Cal Fire crews have responded to nearly 150 wildfires across the state.

Cal Fire is beefing up its staff and getting ready for an intense fire season across California. Last fall, the "King fire" in the Sierras, east of Sacramento, destroyed 80 structures and burned more than 97,000 acres.

This year, fire crews are expecting a busy season.

"Ninety-five percent of the fires we respond to are caused by the activity of people. That means almost every single fire is preventable," Daniel Berlant, a Cal Fire spokesman said.

Fire crews are reminding homeowners to make sure there is 100 ft. of defensible space around their homes.

label.eng: California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection
